resources.string: Embracing sustainable transportation practices is key for reducing carbon footprints. Opting for greener alternatives like walking, biking to campus, carpooling, and using public transportation can significantly reduce emissions.

Collect points to redeem special awards
Ensuring that the information you provide is accurate and up-to-date. Regularly updating the app to benefit from new features and improvements.
4. User Responsibilities You are responsible for:
C-Verde collects and processes personal information, such as your daily activities, energy usage, and travel habits, to calculate your carbon footprint.
Avoid any unauthorized access, tampering, or reverse engineering of the application.
• Use the app for lawful purposes and in compliance with all applicable laws.
• Provide accurate data regarding your activities to ensure accurate carbon footprint tracking.
C-Verde is a carbon footprint tracker that allows users to monitor and reduce their environmental impact. By using the application, you agree to:
By downloading, installing, or using the C-Verde application, you agree to be bound by these Terms and Conditions. If you do not agree to these terms, please do not use the application.

Small choices, big impact! Choose green travel and help the planet!
Replicate the Earth\'s major spheres by making a terrarium.
Replicate the Earth\'s\nmajor spehere by\nmaking a terrarium.
• A container for your terrarium (you may repurpose a large clear wide-mouthed glass jar or a plastic bottle)\n• Small plants like ferns, golden pothos, or moss.\n• Small spade or tool for digging.

1. At the bottom of the jar, dampen the soil and dig enough space for your plants, covering their roots with soil.\n2. Close and seal the terrarium again, then place it near a sunny window.\n3. Observe your plant. Are they able to survive without being watered? Why?
Replicate the Earth\'s major spheres by making a terrarium!
This app is informed by insights from Klimaalam written by Raissa Rivera Falgui illustrated by Harry Monzo (2022).

Try studying your weather\nfor a week. Take note of\nthe weather and temperature.
This experiment demonstrates how Arrhenius \nlinked carbon dioxide to Earth\'s warming.
This experiment demonstrates \nhow Arrhenius linked carbon \ndioxide to Earth\'s warming.
This experiment shows how \ntemperature affects rainfall.
This chapter explores climate change \nimpacts and adaptation methods.
It\'s better to preserve the environment \nthan to deplete natural resources and \nthen seek replacements.

∙ 2 bars of modeling clay
∙ Small objects like rocks or bottle caps to simulate structures
∙ A rectangular container measuring approximately 8 x 13 inches
∙ A tightly sealed drinking bottle shorter than the container’s width
∙ 6 ice cubes

1. Shape the modeling clay into two flat-topped land masses.
2. Position the clay at opposite ends of the container. Fill the container with water until the clay is submerged halfway.
3. Press small objects into one clay mass to represent houses and buildings, ensuring they are placed in various areas above the waterline.
4. Use the plastic bottle to create waves by bouncing or rolling it toward the clay.
5. Place ice cubes on the clay at the opposite end to represent glaciers. Leave the setup in a warm area and observe any changes over time.
6. Once observations are complete, pour out the water and store the setup for future use if desired.
You can see from this activity how melting ice from the cryosphere leads to rise in sea levels.
Acknowledgments This app is informed by insights from Klimaalam written by Raissa Rivera Falgui illustrated by Harry Monzo (2022).
This app is informed by insights from Klimaalam written by Raissa Rivera Falgui illustrated by Harry Monzo (2022).

"Try studying your weather for a week. Take note of the weather and daily temperature at the same time every morning using a thermometer, your phone, or local weather reports. Compute the mean average of the climate calendar in th Philippine Climate Almanac and compare your recorded temperature average against the average temperature for the month. "
Chart the years of these events. Do you observe more extreme events in the recent years?
Try studying your weather for a week. Take note of the weather and daily temperature at the same time every morning using a thermometer, your phone, or local weather reports.
This app is informed by insights from Klimaalam written by Raissa Rivera Falgui illustrated by Harry Monzo (2022).
∙ two thermometers\n∙ a clear glass jar/bottle big enough to hold one of the thermometers.
Do this on a sunny day.

1. Turn both thermometers on and put one inside the jar. Cover it.\n2. Lay the jar in direct sunlight on its side, with the other thermometer beside it, but not touching it. Make sure that the sun is shining directly on both thermometers.\n3. Check temperature after two minutes. Which one has the higher temperature? How many degrees is the difference?
This simple experiment will show how Arrhenius’ observation led him to make the connection between carbon dioxide and the warming of the Earth.
This app is informed by insights from Klimaalam written by Raissa Rivera Falgui illustrated by Harry Monzo (2022).

∙ two identical glass jars or bottles
∙ ceramic saucers
∙ boiling water
∙ 6 ice cubes

1. Fill about 1/2 of one jar with room temperature water and the other with the same amount of boiling water.\n2. Place a saucer on the top of each jar.\n3. After three minutes, put three ice cubes in each saucer.

In the experiment, water quickly evaporates and condenses in the jar with hot water. In the same way, greater heat causes more water from the surface of the Earth to evaporate, condense, then turn into rain.
"This experiment will show how an increase in temperature make a difference in the amount of rainfall. "
This app is informed by insights from Klimaalam written by Raissa Rivera Falgui illustrated by Harry Monzo (2022).
∙ the model you made in melting ice experiment, refilled with water.\n∙ empty water bottle.\n∙ a pack of toothpicks or fallen branches, flower stems or plants.\t

1. Study your current model. What do you think can be done to prevent the waves from reaching the houses?\n2. Try making a barrier by sticking toothpicks up in the clay along the waterline.\n3. Roll the bottle to make waves. How successful is your barrier? What else do you think you could do to keep water from reaching the houses and buildings? Try it on your model. Compare your methods and results with each of your classmates.
In this chapter, you will get to learn about the impacts of climate change and think or more methods of adapting to it.
This app is informed by insights from Klimaalam written by Raissa Rivera Falgui illustrated by Harry Monzo (2022).
List down the most common climate hazards where you live. Which is your community most at risk of in the rainy season? In the dry season?
"List down the common ways that help you adapt to these top climate hazards. Assess whether any of you answers are forms of maladaptation. Come up with better alternatives for the maladaptations. "
“Sustainable development is to make the world a better place for everyone now, without destroying the possibilities for the next generations.” - Arindam Basu
"It is better to maintain the state of the environment than to wait until we have significantly depleted natural resources before trying to replace them. "
This app is informed by insights from Klimaalam written by Raissa Rivera Falgui illustrated by Harry Monzo (2022).
